A small company [action]manufactures[/action] [entity]customized bicycles[/entity].

Whenever the [entity]sales department[/entity] [action]receives[/action] [entity]an order[/entity], a new process instance is [action]created[/action].

A [entity]member of the sales department[/entity] can then [action]reject[/action] or [action]accept[/action] [entity]the order for a customized bike[/entity].

In the former case, the process instance is [action]finished[/action].

In the latter case, the [entity]storehouse and the engineering department[/entity] are [action]informed[/action].

The [entity]storehouse[/entity] immediately [action]processes[/action] [entity]the part list of the order[/entity] and [action]checks[/action] [entity]the required quantity of each part[/entity].

[condition]If the part is available in-house[/condition], it is [action]reserved[/action].

[condition]If it is not available[/condition], it is [action]back-ordered[/action].

This procedure is [action]repeated[/action] for [entity]each item on the part list[/entity].

In the meantime, the [entity]engineering department[/entity] [action]prepares[/action] [entity]everything for the assembling of the ordered bicycle[/entity].

[condition]If the storehouse has successfully reserved or back-ordered every item of the part list and the preparation activity has finished[/condition], the [entity]engineering department[/entity] [action]assembles[/action] [entity]the bicycle[/entity].

Afterwards, the [entity]sales department[/entity] [action]ships[/action] [entity]the bicycle to the customer[/entity] and [action]finishes[/action] [entity]the process instance[/entity].
